title: Hardware requirements for other options
content:
If none of the typical deployment options described previously meets your needs, use the following guidelines.

How to calculate hardware resources

You can determine your hardware requirements as follows:

  1. Use the deployment size definitions for the SMA capability to determine the SMA deployment size and required hardware resources (see Hardware requirements for option 1). Use this hardware resource requirement as a basis.
  2. Use the deployment size definitions for each of the other desired capabilities to determine their deployment size and additional hardware resources required.
  3. Calculate the total hardware resources required by adding up the requirements for all capabilities, and add resources as needed: worker nodes, CPU, RAM, and disk storage. Note that when calculating how many worker nodes are needed, keep in mind that all worker nodes must have the same hardware specification provided here because Kubernetes schedules pods across all of the worker nodes.
For more information about NFS storage sizing, see Manage persistent storage for the suite.

    Performance tuning for CMP FinOps

    This section contains configuration changes required to support a higher number of Cloud Cost Provider integrations (small, medium, and large sizing profiles)

    Configure node group on your OMT portal

    On your OMT portal, configure the following parameters as part of node grouping based on your sizing profile.

    • Node group name. Example: cgro
    • Desired size (node count). Example: 8
    • Add Kubernetes label. Example: Worker cgro.

    Update 'nodeSelector' parameter

    1. Use the following steps to update the nodeSelector parameter.
    2. Locate the itom-cgro-showback sub-chart in the cgro-showback.yaml file and copy the sub-chart details. 
      itom-cgro-showback:
    replicas: 1
    global:
      nodeSelector:
    3. Save the copied content to a new YAML file (for example, cgro_nodeSelector.yaml), append the first line as the service chart name cgro:, and then then update the nodeSelector. 
      cgro:
  itom-cgro-showback:
    replicas: 1
    global:
      nodeSelector:
        Worker: "cgro"
    4. Run the following command to apply this update: 
      helm get values $releaseName -n $NAMESPACE > my-values.yaml
helm upgrade $releaseName <ESM_HELM_CHART_PATH> -n $NAMESPACE -f  my-values.yaml -f <CUSTOM_REPLICAS.yaml>

      Where:

      • <ESM_HELM_CHART_PATH> is the absolute path of the helm package.
      • <CUSTOM_REPLICAS.yaml> is your customized YAML file, which you prepared in the previous step. For example, cgro_nodeSelector.yaml.

      Example:

      helm upgrade sma esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx\charts\esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx.tgz -n itsma-xxx -f my-values.yaml -f cgro_nodeSelector.yaml

      For more details, see How to update nodeSelector.

    5. To update the CGRO_SHOWBACK_COLLECT_COPY_STREAM_RESOURCE_POOL_NAME setting in the itom-cgro-showback-deployment:
      1. Copy the following content to a new YAML file (for example, cgro_copy_stream.yaml): 
        cgro:
  itom-cgro-showback:
    collect:
      copy_stream_resource_pool_name: "itom_finops_etl"
      2. Change the value of the copy_stream_resource_pool_name property to the required value and save the file.
    6. Run the following command to apply this update: 
      helm upgrade sma esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx\charts\esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx.tgz -n itsma-xxx -f my-values.yaml -f cgro_copy_stream.yaml

    Separate ETL and query workloads

    Perform the following tasks to divide ETL workloads and query workloads into separate resource pools.

    1. On the Vertica database, as a database administrator, run the following command to create a custom ETL resource pool.

      For small profile:

       CREATE RESOURCE POOL itom_finops_etl MAXMEMORYSIZE '40%' PLANNEDCONCURRENCY 64 MAXCONCURRENCY 64;

      For medium and large proflies:

      CREATE RESOURCE POOL itom_finops_etl MAXMEMORYSIZE '40%' PLANNEDCONCURRENCY 128 MAXCONCURRENCY 128;
    2. Run the following commands to validate that the new resource pools are created: 
      SELECT * from RESOURCE_POOLS
SELECT * from RESOURCE_POOL_STATUS
    3. Perform the following configuration changes on the Vertica database as a Vertica Database Administrator

      For small profile:

      ALTER RESOURCE POOL general PLANNEDCONCURRENCY 32;
ALTER RESOURCE POOL general MAXCONCURRENCY 32;

      For medium and large profiles:

      ALTER RESOURCE POOL general PLANNEDCONCURRENCY 64;
ALTER RESOURCE POOL general MAXCONCURRENCY 64;
    4. Run the following commands on the bastion host to restart the pods: 
      kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-costpolicy --replicas=0 -n <itsma_namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-costpolicy --replicas=1 -n <itsma_namespace>
 
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-insights --replicas=0 -n <itsma_namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-insights --replicas=1 -n <itsma_namespace>
 
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-insights-gateway --replicas=0 -n <itsma_namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-insights-gateway --replicas=1 -n <itsma_namespace>
 
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-policy-gateway --replicas=0 -n <itsma_namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-policy-gateway --replicas=1 -n <itsma_namespace>
 
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-showback --replicas=0 -n <itsma_namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-showback --replicas=1 -n <itsma_namespace>
 
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-showback-gateway --replicas=0 -n <itsma_namespace>
kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-showback-gateway --replicas=1 -n <itsma_namespace>
    5. Scale up the showback pod as needed. For example, run the following command on the bastion host to scale up the replica to 2. 
      kubectl scale deployment itom-cgro-showback --replicas=2 -n <itsma_namespace>
      See the table above for specific replica counts based on workloads.

    Additional hardware requirements for UCMDB

    If using a classic UCMDB

    If you plan to use classic UCMDB, install UCMDB Gateway on the UCMDB Server, and add the following minimal resources for UCMDB Gateway (for classic UCMDB hardware resource requirements, see Classic UD/UCMDB sizing recommendations):

    Deployment CPU RAM Disk Space
    All sizes 4 cores 2 GB (allocated for UCMDB Gateway only) 100 GB

    If using the containerized UCMDB

    If you plan to install the containerized UCMDB (as the next deployment on the same OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT)), use the following guidelines to determine the additional hardware resources required for UCMDB.

    1. Determine the UCMDB deployment size.
      Deployment size Small Medium Large
      Maximum number of CIs and Relationships in UCMDB 10 million 60 million 200 million
    2. Determine the additional hardware requirements according to your UCMDB deployment size.
